awd_titl_txt: An Historical Study of Mendelian Genetics and Virus Disease Resistance Genes
awd_abstract_narration:
General Audience Summary 

This research project in history of plant biology will bring to light some of the attempts by 20th century biologists to develop plants that are resistant to virus infection. It will also explore important connections between basic research in the lab and practical applications valued in agricultural contexts. The focus of the research will be Francis O. Holmes, a scientist at the Rockefeller Institute of Medical Research, who developed an influential paradigm for plant resistance centered on the tobacco mosaic virus. In the 1930s Holmes developed new ideas about what genetic resistance to plant viruses was and how it could be controlled in the hands of scientists. He put this work into practice by producing crop plants with genetic resistance to the tobacco mosaic virus. From his extensive laboratory and greenhouse experiments, he developed a hypothesis that wild plants and viruses co-evolved in discrete geographical locations. The investigator will determine the development and application of these ideas that continue to be used today by plant breeders to improve cultivated varieties. The findings will be integrated into undergraduate and graduate courses that explore the topics of emerging diseases, virology, virus/plant co-evolution and ecology, and broader issues of food safety. The results will be disseminated through publications, classroom and public lectures, undergraduate and graduate student training, and communication with plant scientists and historians of science, to bridge interdisciplinary boundaries.

Technical Summary 

The focus of this research is on the development of the theory of co-evolution of host:pathogen diversity in plant pathology, with a particular concentration on knowledge production derived from tobacco mosaic virus (TMV), an intriguing object of scientific and historical study, and the experimental and theoretical work of Francis Holmes. When Holmes wrote this co-evolutionary thesis in 1951, it was strikingly innovative; it brought together Mendelian genetics as well as contemporary findings of plant evolutionary biology, virology, epidemiology, and ecology by demonstrating the plasticity of plant genomes and the role of the environment in host:pathogen interactions. This research will show how Holmes developed the practical tools and expertise to test his hypothesis that inter-species hybrids of tobacco could be used to produce TMV-resistant plants. It will also show how his experiments informed his hypothesis that the geographical center for host plants of TMV would also provide a wealth of resistance genes. Finally, it will use a hands-on approach as to how Holmes trafficked across boundaries from the lab to the field to identify and deploy resistant genes to virus infections; the focus will be on Capsicum (pepper and Tabasco), which resulted in many plant cultivars that are still in use today.

por.por_cntn:
The project “An Historical Study of Mendelian Genetics and Virus Disease Resistance Genes” was built around the gaps in our understanding of early to mid-20th century research to determine the nature of viruses and how to interpret host-virus interactions towards deploying disease resistance in crops. In particular, this work centered on Francis O. Holmes, a virologist studying tobacco mosaic virus (TMV), first at the Boyce Thompson Institute for Plant Research, then at the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research. Holmes had made the discovery that TMV, when inoculated to certain plants, induced localized necrotic lesions (LNLs) that could be used as a marker for infection by counting the lesions to determine an approximate virus titer. From this, Holmes made an imaginative leap, realizing that the LNL response was a also a marker for a dominant genetic host response to TMV infection. He hypothesized that a gene N (for necrotic) was associated with resistance in Nicotiana glutinosa, a wild tobacco species; and the gene L (for localization) in Tabasco pepper (Capsicum frutescens). In both instances, Holmes used the then relatively new principles of Mendelian genetics for N- and L-resistance gene introgression to commercial lines of tobacco and bell pepper, respectively. His successes with this strategy were rapidly taken up by plant pathologists and plant breeders, ushering in a new era of crop plants genetically resistant to the ravages of plant virus diseases.

Three areas were addressed during this project: understanding Holmes’ strategy and his difficulties in developing hybrid tobacco plants for TMV resistance, which lead to his pathbreaking research using Capsicum species; recreating his experiment that showed LNLs were followed by leaf abscission when Tabasco pepper (L-gene) was inoculated with TMV; and exploring his ideas that viruses and hosts co-evolve in regions that are centers of diversity/origin for wild plant species. In particular, his hypothesis, before the establishment of plate tectonics, that TMV and other disease resistance genes in solanaceous plants (pepper, tomato, tobacco) would be concentrated in South America. The most interesting outcome of this project was related to the replication of Holmes’ TMV-Tabasco experiment, one of the few examples of an historical reworking of an experiment in the life sciences. This reworking is also important as it directly touches on the current concerns regarding reproducibility in science, sometimes labeled a “crisis”. We determined that it is exceeding difficult to replicate experiments, even a “simple” experiment performed in 1934, that although ideas travel across the decades, the materials (plants, viruses, reagents) do not. This has important lessons as the scientific community struggles to determine which experiments should be replicated and what meaning can be ascribed to replicating and reworking experiments. A half-dozen undergraduate and graduate students have assisted with this work, some of whom co-authored a peer-reviewed manuscript. This work and its offshoots has resulted in two book chapters, a dozen peer-reviewed articles (published and in preparation), a book contract, several invited lectures, and new lectures incorporated into “Pathogens, the Environment and Society,” undergraduate course.
